awd_titl_txt: Reconstructing Ancient Human and Ecosystem Responses to Holocene Climate Conditions
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will reconstruct Holocene climatic conditions to better understand human adaptation and response to past environmental variability.  The investigators will use an array of archaeological materials and atmospheric proxies from Northern Rocky Mountain ice cores to better understand human use of alpine environments during periods of dramatic environmental change.  This project will provide new insights into what the large-scale environmental changes were, how such changes impacted humans, and what strategies humans used to respond and adapt to these changes.  The project will involve a collaboration among tribal communities, universities, agencies, and land managers, with students from tribal colleges and universities being educated and trained to help constitute the next generation of researchers, natural resource managers, and educators.  Tribal elders, tribal community members, and students will be brought together to discuss the significance and meaning of the archaeological artifacts from the context of tribal oral traditions and histories and to document and share the findings.

The diverse assemblages of plant, animal, geologic, and archaeological material rapidly emerging from melting ice-patches in higher-elevation areas can provide a wealth of information about past environmental conditions and human use of alpine resources.  Coupling biological and geochemical records preserved in ice patches with evidence from archaeological sites presents a rare opportunity to document and evaluate human response and adaptation to large-scale climate patterns and pronounced climate events.  The investigators will focus on four core questions: (1) What is the long-term climate history of high-elevation regions?  (2) How did changes in climate and environmental conditions influence human and animal use of the alpine zone?  (3) What were the long-term strategies of indigenous North Americans in response to extreme droughts and cold, wet periods?  (4) What do the array of materials exposed from melting ice patches reveal about human capacity for change?  These questions will be addressed by evaluating archaeological artifacts, ancient wood, and environmental and climatic proxies (e.g., oxygen isotopes, black carbon, continental dust, charcoal, and pollen) found frozen in ice-cores within ice-patches.  The ice-core reconstructions will be compared with records of past hydroclimatic changes from adjacent lake-sediment sites.  A subregional index of intensity of human use will be developed by documenting temporal intervals of increased presence/absence and abundance of archeological materials.  The project's research outcomes will provide new information about human response to dramatic climate and environmental change, thereby advancing basic understanding of the resilience of socioecological systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Alpine snow and ice patches are melting at an unprecedented rate in response to changing weather patterns and climate worldwide. These exceptional records are revealing a trove of archeological materials including woven baskets, dart shafts, other hunting technology, along with numerous animal and plant remains, remains that have been locked in ice for thousands of years but are now at risk of being lost through exposure and rapid degradation. The diverse assemblages of plant, animal, geologic, and archaeological material rapidly emerging from melting ice-patches in higher-elevation areas can provide a wealth of information about past environmental conditions and human use of alpine resources. Our investigator team set out to analyze new multiproxy records from semi-permanent ice patches to answer the following questions: 1) What is the long-term climate history of high-elevation regions? (2) How did changes in climate and environmental conditions influence human and animal use of the high alpine? These questions were addressed by evaluating archaeological artifacts, ancient wood, and environmental and climatic proxies (e.g., oxygen isotopes, black carbon, continental dust, charcoal, and pollen) found frozen in ice-cores within ice-patches.

Intellectual Merit

Results from our research efforts have significantly advanced and paved the way for the development of ice patch records as enduring archives of climate and environmental change, utilizing stable isotopes, pollen, charcoal and other proxies contained within ice patch layers. The investigator team achieved a milestone by publishing the first-ever Holocene-length δ18O isotope record from an inland ice patch, documenting winter/spring moisture and storm intensity. Building on this groundbreaking record, we expanded our research by creating replicate climate and environmental change records from several neighboring ice patches. Additionally, samples retrieved from a mature ancient whitebark pine forest found within one of the ice patches revealed a striking treeline advance that correlated with early- to mid-Holocene temperature increases. By coupling an annually-resolved tree-ring climate record from the whitebark pine samples with modern tree-ring records from nearby downslope tree patches, we demonstrated that the current warming trends align with the mid-Holocene warming, implying that present conditions, except for potential water limitations and/or late snowpack, will likely promote rapid upslope treeline advancements and the eventual loss of ice patches in the upcoming decades.

Radiocarbon dating of basal carbon from several ice patches indicates that many of the high-alpine ice patches formed approximately 5,000-6,000 years ago. This finding supports the Holocene-length ice patch record, which revealed rapid mid-Holocene warming was followed by much wetter and cooler conditions. These records also complement a rich archive of archaeological data indicating significant fluctuations in human activity in the high-alpine regions, with most of the increases in human activity associated with warming. The numerous bison driveline sites and hunting implements found adjacent to or within the ice patches further underscore the high-alpine environments' importance for hunting, ceremonies, travel, and short- and long-term use.

 Broader Impacts

 The project involved a diverse collaboration of agency, university, tribal and community partnerships. Tribal members and students from several regional tribes (Crow, Blackfeet, Shoshone) participated in fieldwork, outreach and science synthesis. Two tribal graduate students at Montana State University contributed to the research project and were involved in science synthesis. The project supported several young researchers including four graduate students 1 PhD University of Nevada Reno/Desert Research Institute and 3 MSc at Montana State University. Project investigators developed a traveling exhibit that was hosted by several museums, tribal schools and institutions in Wyoming, Montana, Colorado and Utah including: the Montana State Historical Society; Park County Museum, Montana; Wyoming State Museum, Cheyenne; Utah State University Museum, Logan; Yellowstone National Park’s Heritage and Research Center (YHC), Gardiner; and the University of Colorado’s Museum of Natural History, Boulder. Investigators successfully organized and participated in the 5th International Frozen Pasts Glacial and Ice Patch Archaeology Conference, Pray, Montana. The team also hosted a Science Synthesis Workshop in September 2022, bringing together a diverse group of scientists, agency personnel and students to discuss project results and implications.

Summary

The results achieved with support from this grant have laid a strong foundation for future development of multiproxy datasets from inland ice patches. Investigating the last remaining ice patches and the archeological materials associated with these ice patches will prove crucial as our paleo tree-ring transfer model of temperature indicates that current conditions will be unable to sustain the existence of ice patches in the coming decades. There is an urgent need to recover climate and environmental records from ice patches before they are lost.
